title: 103_s2479
content: The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels in the country. It amends the Act of June 19, 1886 to facilitate coastwise transportation of passengers. In coastwise trade, a vessel can transport passengers if owned by a U.S. citizen or entity, meets Merchant Marine Act requirements, and is at least 5 net tons. In coastwise trade, a vessel over 5 net tons can get a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement. An exception is made for cruise vessels under an 18-month demise charter to a qualified person, allowing them to operate in coastwise trade. Authorized vessels under a demise charter in coastwise trade can operate for up to 6 months after the charter ends with approval from the Secretary and compliance with specified terms. An exception is made for cruise vessels undergoing reflagging. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows a cruise vessel to be documented under chapter 121 of title 46 if it is between 5 and 15 years old and the owner has entered into a construction contract. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows a cruise vessel to be documented under chapter 121 of title 46 if it is between 5 and 15 years old and the owner has entered into a construction contract for another cruise vessel with a berth capacity of at least 80 percent. This authority terminates 18 months after the issuance of a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement if a new vessel's keel has not been laid before that period ends. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows a cruise vessel to be documented under chapter 121 of title 46 if it is between 5 and 15 years old and the owner has entered into a construction contract for another cruise vessel with a berth capacity of at least 80 percent. This authority terminates 18 months after the issuance of a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement if a new vessel's keel has not been laid before that period ends. The Secretary of Transportation may extend the 18-month period for an additional 6 months for good cause shown. A person who owns or charters a cruise vessel operating in coastwise trade under a coastwise endorsement may not operate any vessel between. A person operating a vessel in violation of this section is liable to the United States Government for a civil penalty of $1,000 for each passenger transported in violation of this section. A vessel operated in knowing violation of this section, and its equipment, are liable to seizure. A person operating a vessel in violation of this section is liable to the United States Government for a civil penalty of $1,000 for each passenger transported. Vessels operated in knowing violation are subject to seizure and forfeiture. Additionally, individuals involved in construction contracts for cruise vessels may be disqualified from coastwise trade if construction milestones are not met within the specified period. In this section, definitions for 'coastwise trade', 'cruise vessel', and 'related person' are provided. Coastwise trade includes passenger transportation within the US or via a foreign port. A cruise vessel must be over 10,000 gross tons, have accommodations for 200 passengers, and not be a ferry. A related person is defined in relation to an individual. The term 'related person' is defined as a holding company, subsidiary, affiliate, or association of a person, as well as an officer, director, or agent of the person or any entity related to them. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to deem vessels meeting specific standards as compliant with certain subtitle parts. The Secretary is required to issue a certificate of inspection to these vessels, which must meet criteria for control verification certificates and have a coastwise endorsement. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows vessels to engage in coastwise trade if authorized under section 12106 of the Act approved on June 19, 1886. SEC. 5. CITIZENSHIP FOR PURPOSES OF DOCUMENTATION. Section 2 of the Shipping Act, 1916 is amended to include new provisions regarding citizenship requirements for operating vessels primarily in the transport of passengers in coastwise trade. Ownership by citizens of the United States is now required for a majority interest in partnerships or associations that own such vessels. Ownership by US citizens is required for partnerships or associations that own vessels for passenger transport in coastwise trade. Amendment to Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 includes changes to passenger and cargo regulations. Permits for vessels entering units of the National Park System are also addressed. The Secretary of the Interior has priority rules for vessel operation in National Park System units. Priority is given to vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. The Secretary of the Interior has priority rules for vessel operation in National Park System units. Priority is given to vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Any person operating a foreign-documented vessel in a National Park System unit may have their permission revoked by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior has restrictions on revoking permits for operating vessels in National Park System units. Permission cannot be denied to individuals with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Any person whose permission to provide visitor services in a National Park System unit is revoked or not renewed has the right of first refusal for a new permit when conditions change. This right is limited to the number of permits affected.
